M.J. (Helen Hudson) runs through the crowd and corridors, actively searching for the source of a scream, pushing open doors and reacting quickly.
M.J. bursts into a room with a gun drawn, only to find stoned students playing and mocking her, which undermines her authority and control in the situation.
Lies wide awake in the dark, concerned and attentive to the phone call, trying to communicate with Peter despite danger.
Plea to Peter to leave M.J. out of the conflict and let her go, offering herself instead.
Shows concern for M.J.'s safety despite the danger to herself.
Identifies the suspect (Daryll Lee Cullum) quickly, showing insight.
Negotiates with Peter to save M.J. by offering herself, demonstrating calm and strategic thinking under pressure.
Shows willingness to sacrifice herself to protect a colleague, indicating confidence and decisiveness.
Tells Fred it's all over and encourages him to go home, offers her phone to call in, showing concern for his well-being.
Reloads Ruben's gun with trembling fingers, indicating fear or anxiety but also a protective instinct.
Steps resolutely into the hall, bracing herself for reassurance, showing vulnerability and self-support.
Pulls out Ruben's gun from bathroom drawer and reloads it despite trembling fingers.
Steps resolutely into the hall and braces herself on the wall for reassurance, gradually gaining confidence as she moves.
Moves with more confidence, overcomes agoraphobia to go outside and drive at night despite fear.
Warns Saks that Sergeant Halloran will kill someone if he sees or hears the police, showing concern for others' safety.
Moves with more and more confidence; her agoraphobia is gone; she steels herself and runs to her car despite difficult conditions.
Recognizes that her phone was tapped and quickly deduces the situation with Saks and the SWAT team; attempts to warn them about Sergeant Halloran inside.
Stops the car and cooperates with Saks despite tension, showing situational awareness and control.
Jams on the gas to escape Saks who tries to pull her from the car, causing him to fall but preventing him from being taken by the threat.
Walks alone into the dark auditorium despite fear and vertigo, showing determination but no direct interaction with others.
Jams on the gas to escape Saks who tries to pull her from the car, successfully evading capture.
Stops the car quietly and moves cautiously into the auditorium, listening carefully and trying to detect any presence.
Maintains composure despite vertigo and distorted vision, continuing to move forward and investigate.
Fails to see Peter immediately despite careful listening and observation, indicating some sensory limitation.
Paralyzed and unable to warn the cop despite having time, fascinated by the terrible event.
Pulls out Ruben's gun and cautiously enters the ladies' room, firing to check for danger.
Paralyzed and fascinated, fails to warn the cop despite having ample time.
Recovers from paralysis, pulls out a gun, and cautiously fires into the closet to investigate a sound.
Rushes to assist M.J. who is hanging by a noose, showing immediate concern and willingness to help.
Is disarmed and left horrified after M.J. is shot by Peter, showing vulnerability and emotional reaction.
Fires two rounds into the broom closet door upon hearing a sound, attempting to neutralize a potential threat.
Moves cautiously along the stalls, pushing doors open to search for M.J., showing methodical and careful behavior.
Rushes to assist M.J. upon seeing her hanging by a noose, demonstrating quick concern but possibly impulsive action.
Is disarmed from behind by Peter after the lights go out, indicating a lapse in situational awareness or vulnerability.
Lies on the floor, horror-struck after witnessing M.J. being shot, showing emotional shock and temporary incapacitation.
Tells Peter to kill her, challenging him to have the courage to end the carnage.
Uses psychological wiles to try to take control of the situation with Peter on stage.
Tells Peter to kill her, seemingly resigned and emotionally vulnerable.
Moves with Peter without resistance as he turns out the lights, showing no physical resistance or attempt to escape.
Admits to having no life and feeling responsible for ruining Peter's life, offers herself to him to stop the violence.
Corrects Peter's misconception about who she admires, emphasizing admiration for good artists and thinkers rather than murderers.
Offers to help Peter and tries to negotiate with him to put the knife down, showing presence of mind under pressure.
Acknowledges her ruined life and accepts blame, showing emotional vulnerability but also self-awareness.
Expresses willingness to love and help Peter, offering understanding and peace of mind.
Encourages M.J. to shoot Peter to save herself and others.
Notices the shadow behind Peter quickly and uses this awareness to provoke him into firing prematurely, then head butts him with astonishing strength, knocking him backward.
Maintains calm and control under extreme threat, looking directly into Peter's eyes and commanding M.J. to shoot, demonstrating leadership and presence of mind.
Sits down next to M.J. and helps her put on her shirt despite M.J.'s pain.
Helps M.J. put on her shirt despite the difficult situation, showing calmness and care.
Sits down next to M.J. after the explosion and shooting, remaining present and supportive.
Recognizes that the only person who could provide crucial information is dead, showing awareness of the situation's gravity.
Does not insist on giving her statement despite the pressure, indicating self-awareness and understanding of her current limitations.
Tells M.J. she needs a ride home instead of herself, showing concern for M.J.'s well-being.
Responds to Susan's question with a dismissive remark, 'If she has to ask, she's never gonna know.'
Shows confidence by insisting she can drive herself home despite others' concern.
Responds to media intrusion with a calm, dismissive remark indicating control over the situation.
